heading: break it to me gently online
subheading: a new study finds that electronic communication makes correspondence more honest. or does it simply break down inhibitions? by kristen philipkoski.
author: kristen philipkoski
text: a new study shows that people may be more honest when delivering bad news via email rather than in person or by phone. that may come as no surprise to anyone who's received a royal flaming. but the researchers claim their conclusions may help businesses run more smoothly."say you're working remotely on marketing package and your supervisor says [via email] 'it's not very good, make it better.' in terms of learning, people learn by getting constructive criticism -� we learn more from our mistakes," said stephanie watts sussman, lead author of the study and assistant professor in information systems at the weatherhead school of management at case western reserve university in cleveland.sussman said coworkers are more likely to deliver constructive criticism via email than in person or by phone."a lot of it is making people more honest because their inhibitions are lower," sussman said.malcolm parks, an internet communications researcher at the university of washington, takes a different view."i don't think there's any evidence to support the notion that people are generally more accurate. they're simply more expressive," parks said."sometimes you might say more than you mean and be overly expressive, which can mean you're inaccurate," he added. "in fact, millions of us have had the experience of sending an email message only to realize we said something too quickly. so the medium can facilitate an amount of inaccuracy."in the study, published in the journal of the institute for operations research and the management sciences, the researchers asked 117 boston university undergraduates to deliver either positive or negative information to other study participants who posed as fellow students.pointing out mistakes in the résumés caused the messengers "considerable discomfort," the study subjects reported in a questionnaire.was it easier to get bad news in an email than in person or over the phone? that's a question for a follow-up study."the big limitation of the work is we didn't look at it from the perspective of the recipient," sussman said.
